```{python}
import re

string1="We have to extract these numbers 12, 47, 48 The integers numbers are also interesting: 189 2036 314\',\' is a separator, so please extract these numbers 125,789,1450 and also these 564,90456 We like to offer you 7890$ per month in order to complete this task... we are joking"
```

Detecting the DNA restriction enzyme binding sites of ANTAAT and GCRWTG. In the first binding site, "N" could represent any of the four nucleotides (A, T, G, or C). In the second binding site, "R" could be A or G (purines) and "W" could be A or T (complementary bases).
```{python}
string5=""

re.findall(r"A[AGTC]TAAT",string5)
re.findall(r"GC[AG][AT]TG",string5)
```

Finding k-mers, or all the possible, unique sub-sequences from two strings of nucleotide bases.
```{python}
my_seq1 = "ATCATCATG"
my_seq2 = "CAGCCCAATCAGGCTCTACTGCCACTAAACTTACGCAGGATATATTTACGCCGACGTACT"

def kmers(dna):  #argument "sentence" will be string object
    counts = {}  #new dict
    for i in range(0,len(dna)-2):
        if dna[i:i+3] in counts:     #have we seen it before in this sentence?
            counts[dna[i:i+3]]+= 1   #if yes, increase count by 1
        else:
            counts[dna[i:i+3]] = 1   #otherwise, set count
    return(counts)
        
kmers(my_seq1)
kmers(my_seq2)
```
